title: 108_s759
content: The Act is titled the "Residential, Farm, Ranch, and Small Business Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003" or the "Small Wind Energy Systems Act of 2003." It introduces a credit for residential small wind energy systems under the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act allows a 30% tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures by individuals. The credit is capped at $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures is capped at $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity and requires safety certifications. Unused credits can be carried forward to the succeeding taxable year. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property expenditures is defined as an expenditure for qualified wind energy property installed on a dwelling unit in the US used as a residence by the taxpayer, including installation fees. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property applies to qualifying wind turbines with a 5-year limited warranty for defects in design, material, or workmanship, and installation. The tax credit applies to qualifying wind turbines of 75 kilowatts or less with a 5-year limited warranty for defects in installation. Labor costs are also included in the expenditures. Expenditures for labor costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified wind energy property are eligible for the tax credit. Costs for piping or wiring to connect the property to the energy grid are also included. Expenditures for energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not eligible. For tax credit purposes, energy storage mediums with functions other than storage are not considered. Special rules apply for jointly occupied dwelling units regarding the allowable credit amount based on expenditures made during the year. The allowable tax credit for jointly occupied dwelling units is determined by treating all individuals as one taxpayer for the calendar year. Each individual can claim a credit for their share of expenditures made during the year. The tax credit for jointly occupied dwelling units is calculated based on the ratio of individual expenditures to total expenditures for all individuals in the calendar year. Tenant-stockholders in cooperative housing corporations are also eligible for this credit. Individuals who are stockholders in cooperative housing corporations or members of condominium management associations are treated as having made their proportionate share of any expenditures of the corporation or association, respectively. Individuals in cooperative housing corporations or condominium management associations are considered to have made their proportionate share of expenditures. A condominium management association refers to an organization meeting specific requirements for a residential condominium project. Allocation of expenditures for qualified wind energy property is based on the percentage of nonbusiness use and energy generation for sale. Only the portion of expenditures allocable to nonbusiness use and energy generation for sale is considered. The timing and amount of expenditures are also specified. Expenditures for qualified wind energy property are considered made when the installation is completed and the property is used for energy generation. Expenditures for construction or reconstruction of a structure are treated as made when the taxpayer begins using the structure. The amount of expenditure is the cost thereof. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not taken into account for determining the amount of expenditures made by an individual with respect to a dwelling unit. Expenditures made from subsidized energy financing are not considered for determining the amount of expenditures made for qualified wind energy property. The basis adjustments reduce the increase in property basis by the amount of the credit allowed. This section does not apply to property installed after December 31, 2008. The credit is allowed against regular tax and alternative minimum tax. The credit allowed under subsection (a) for the taxable year shall not exceed the excess of the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, over the credits allowable under this. The credit allowed for the taxable year shall not exceed the regular tax liability plus the tax imposed by section 55, over the sum of allowable credits under this subpart and section 27. Conforming amendments are made to related sections of the Code. The sections of the Code are amended to include subsection (b)(3), section 25C, and sections 23, 25B, and 25C. Section 25B(g)(2), 26(a)(1), 904(h), and 1400C(d) of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include section 25C in addition to sections 23 and 25B. Section 25B(g)(2), 26(a)(1), 904(h), and 1400C(d) of the Internal Revenue Code are amended to include section 25C in addition to sections 23 and 25B. Amendments also include inserting section 25C in various sections of the Code for taxable years before January 1, 2004. Amendments include inserting section 25C in various sections of the Internal Revenue Code for taxable years before January 1, 2004. Amendments to the Internal Revenue Code before January 1, 2004 include inserting section 25C in various sections. The amendments made by section 25C apply to residential wind energy property expenditures after December 31, 2002, in taxable years ending after that date. Subsection (b) amendments apply to taxable years starting after December 31, 2003. Additionally, a credit is provided for business installation of small wind energy property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. This applies to subsection (a) of section 48, with specific criteria outlined for qualified wind energy property. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include qualified wind energy property installed before January 1, 2009. Qualified wind energy property is defined as a qualifying wind turbine installed on a farm, ranch, or eligible small business in the United States owned and used by the taxpayer. Qualified wind energy property in the United States must be owned and used by the taxpayer, have the original use commence with the taxpayer, and carry at least a 5-year limited warranty. The taxpayer must own and use qualified wind energy property in the US, with the original use starting with the taxpayer and a 5-year limited warranty. The tax credit for such property placed in service during the taxable year is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity. The tax credit for qualifying wind turbines is limited to 30% of the property's basis or $1,000 per kilowatt of capacity for turbines of 75 kilowatts or less meeting performance standards. The tax credit for qualified wind energy property is subject to performance and safety standards set by industry associations. The energy percentage limit under the Internal Revenue Code is amended accordingly. The energy percentage for qualified wind energy property is 30 percent, and for other energy property, it is 10 percent. A conforming amendment is made to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. These amendments apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003. The amendments made by this subsection apply to property placed in service after December 31, 2003, under rules similar to section 48(m) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986.
